moves.1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bc4 Bc5: Black chooses a classical setup: Giuoco Piano is on the menu...
moves.9. exd5 Nxd5 10. a3: taking a diversion from modern theory: Qb3, Be6, will usually lead to calm play with few prospects...
moves.10... Qe7+: trying to bring Whites' play out of balance: better was 0-0...
moves.11. Qe2 Be6: slow, but solid: but this gives White a chance to gain tempo...
moves.16. Kh1 Nf4 17. Rfe1 Qd7 18. Ne5 Nxe5 19: Black has won a pawn: but now, it is Whites' turn...
moves.22. Rd7 c5: a creative solution: but Black miscalculated...
moves.23. Rxb7: also bxc5, Qxc5, Rxb7, wins a pawn back: but this is slightly different; now, c5 gets stuck...
moves.24. bxc5: forcing White into a good move...
moves.24... Qxc5 25. Rc1: Blacks' Queen ends up in a tight spot...
moves.25... Qa3: only move: putting Blacks' Queen out of play for a while...
moves.26. Qc4: taking control: of course, Rc8 is no threat; after Qxc8, Rxc8, Rxc8 mate...
moves.27. e6: now, after Rc8, exf7+: Black is in big trouble...
moves.27... fxe6: so this seems the only solution: the pawn is too dangerous...
moves.28. Qxe6+ Kh8: but White has to take care too: Black has accumulated multiple threats...
moves.29. Qe5+: Rxh7+, Kxh7, Rc7+,  Kh8, Qe5+, Kg8, Qg7, runs mate: but after Kh6 in stead of Kh8, Whites' attack stops; so we need another solution...
